text: I want my work to feel like a form of creative expression — not just execution.
scale: Nope. Work is work, not art class.
That’s not really a priority for me.
It'd be a nice bonus, but not essential.
I think I'd feel stifled without some creativity.
Yes. Expression through work is core to who I am.

text: You’re launching a new app and pitching it to investors. You handle strategy, branding, and rally a team to bring it to life.
scale: Sounds terrifying and stressful.
Only if someone else handled the pressure.
It’s ambitious, but exciting.
That actually sounds really energizing.
Yes. That’s exactly the kind of challenge I want.

text: I feel fulfilled when I support someone else’s growth or success.
scale: I don’t really connect with that.
It’s not something I think about much.
It’s fine, I guess — if it happens naturally.
I genuinely enjoy helping others level up.
Yes. Empowering others gives my work meaning.

text: I enjoy analyzing complex systems or concepts to see how they work.
scale: Not really. That sounds mentally exhausting.
Only if someone else explains it first.
I can get into it occasionally.
I like figuring out how stuff fits together.
Yes. That kind of analysis lights me up.

text: You’re managing the back end of an online store — handling inventory systems, automations, shipping workflows, and making sure every process runs efficiently.
scale: Ugh, that sounds like mindless clicking.
Only if I had really good tools.
It depends on how well the system’s built.
I love creating efficient digital systems.
Absolutely. Optimizing that kind of flow is my jam.

text: Spending the day fixing a bike, setting up gear, or doing something hands-on with tools sounds fun to me.
scale: Nope. That sounds like a nightmare.
Maybe for like 10 minutes.
Could be tolerable, I guess.
Yeah, I'd probably enjoy that kind of work.
Absolutely. Give me the toolkit already.

text: You’re a lawyer — crafting arguments, debating in court, convincing people of your position, and negotiating outcomes.
scale: No way. I’d fold under pressure.
Only if I could stay behind the scenes.
It’s intense, but maybe exciting.
I love the idea of persuasive work.
Yes. I’d eat that job up.

text: I care deeply about making others feel seen and understood.
scale: I don't think that's my responsibility.
That’s nice, but not something I focus on.
I try when I can.
It matters to me more than I admit.
Yes. Making people feel understood is huge for me.

text: You’re a logistics coordinator — managing shipments, organizing schedules, and making sure everything arrives where it needs to, on time.
scale: That sounds like anxiety in spreadsheet form.
Only if there were tools to help.
Could be satisfying in the right system.
I like keeping things moving and on track.
Yes. That kind of structured challenge is my thing.

text: Working outdoors or with my body sounds energizing, not draining.
scale: Nature? Outside? Physical labor? Pass.
I’d rather stay indoors, honestly.
If it's part of the job, sure.
Yeah, being active sounds refreshing.
Absolutely. I need movement and fresh air.

text: I want to influence decisions and drive things forward, not just follow instructions.
scale: No thanks. Tell me what to do and I’ll do it.
Only if no one else steps up.
I like contributing, not leading.
I want to help set the direction.
I need to be in the driver's seat.

text: I could happily spend hours learning about something obscure just for fun.
scale: Absolutely not. Why would I do that?
Only if it's directly useful.
Maybe once in a while.
Yeah, I get into weird rabbit holes sometimes.
YES. I'm fueled by curiosity and Wikipedia spirals.

text: Working in a hospital, school, or nonprofit where I support others directly feels like something I’d find meaningful.
scale: Nope. I need distance from people’s problems.
Maybe, if it wasn't too intense.
It depends on the role and cause.
Yeah, that kind of work feels impactful.
Definitely. That kind of job would fulfill me.

text: You’re managing the operations of a major conference. You keep the schedule tight, the teams on task, and every tiny detail on track.
scale: Nope. I’d crumble under that pressure.
Maybe if I had a checklist and help.
I could see the appeal of that.
I love making sure things run smoothly.
Yes. That kind of order is extremely satisfying to me.

text: Restoring a vintage car, building furniture, or doing DIY projects sounds like something I’d genuinely enjoy.
scale: Not even a little bit.
Only if someone else planned it.
Maybe once in a while.
Yeah, that kind of project sounds cool.
Absolutely. That’s my ideal weekend.

text: I want to feel emotionally connected to the work I’m doing.
scale: Nope. I want efficiency, not feelings.
That sounds a bit overdramatic.
It’s nice when that happens.
I feel best when my work has emotional resonance.
Yes. If I don’t feel it, I can’t do it.

text: Researching ancient civilizations, decoding puzzles, or tracking patterns in data sounds intriguing to me.
scale: I’d rather clean my inbox.
Only if I had to do it.
That sounds mildly interesting.
Yeah, I could get into that.
Totally. I love chasing knowledge trails.

text: I’d enjoy managing schedules, tracking details, or creating systems that keep things running smoothly.
scale: No way. That’s mind-numbing.
Only if no one else would do it.
It’s useful, I guess.
I like keeping things clean and tight.
Yes. That’s my wheelhouse.

text: I'd rather fix something broken than replace it with something new.
scale: Absolutely not. Toss it and move on.
Only if there's no other option.
Maybe, if it’s something simple.
Fixing things sounds kind of satisfying.
Yes. Making it work again feels meaningful.

text: Being able to express myself creatively at work is a non-negotiable.
scale: Hard pass. I don't need that at all.
I can live without it, sure.
It'd be a nice bonus if it's there.
I'd feel a little lost without that outlet.
If I'm not creating, something's missing in me.

text: A research-heavy role like data analysis, lab work, or technical strategy actually sounds appealing.
scale: Absolutely not. Boring central.
Only if the topic was super interesting.
It depends on the environment.
Yeah, I’d enjoy getting deep into it.
Yes. I thrive in roles like that.

text: I love making systems more efficient, predictable, or easy to follow.
scale: Not really. Chaos doesn't bother me.
I only fix things when they’re broken.
I sometimes enjoy cleaning things up.
I like improving systems behind the scenes.
Yes. That kind of streamlining gives me life.

text: Convincing someone to see things my way is actually kind of thrilling.
scale: Noooope. I run from confrontation.
Only if it's really important.
Sometimes, if I'm in the zone.
I love a good debate or pitch.
Let me talk. I was born for this.

text: I often imagine new ways to express ideas, even if I don’t act on them.
scale: Nope. I don’t think like that at all.
Maybe once in a blue moon.
I sometimes notice creative angles.
Yeah, my brain kind of does that automatically.
Constantly. I can’t not see creative possibilities.

text: I’d enjoy a job where I get to move around, use my hands, and make physical things happen.
scale: No thanks. I'd rather not move at all.
That sounds exhausting and unnecessary.
Maybe now and then, if it’s not too intense.
Yeah, that kind of hands-on work feels satisfying.
Absolutely. I need to be *doing*, not just thinking.

text: You’re a lab researcher — running experiments, analyzing results, and trying to uncover patterns no one has seen before.
scale: No thanks. I need more variety.
Only if I had support.
It sounds useful, but intense.
I like that kind of deep, focused work.
Yes. That’s exactly my kind of challenge.

text: Filling out spreadsheets, organizing files, or running logistics makes me feel in control.
scale: Nope. That sounds like slow death.
Maybe, for like 30 minutes.
It’s fine if it helps the team.
Honestly, that kind of order feels good.
Yes. Let me spreadsheet my soul.

text: Writing a novel, creating a comic, or directing a short film feels like something I could see myself doing one day.
scale: No way. That’s not me.
Maybe if I had a wild idea.
It sounds interesting but unlikely.
Yeah, I’ve thought about that.
Yes. I daydream about stuff like that a lot.

text: Helping someone understand something complicated makes me feel genuinely good.
scale: Nope. Sounds like a patience test.
Maybe, but only if I have to.
Sometimes it’s kinda rewarding, I guess.
Yeah, I get a buzz from that.
Absolutely. Helping someone 'get it' is magic.

text: I get energy from pitching ideas, influencing decisions, or driving momentum.
scale: Please no. Just give me a quiet task.
That sounds like a lot of pressure.
I can do it, but it’s not my jam.
I actually like that kind of challenge.
Yes. I live for persuasion, action, and big moves.

text: I think I’d enjoy being a project manager, administrator, or operations coordinator — keeping things running efficiently.
scale: Ugh, that sounds dry.
Only if no one else would do it.
It has its appeal, I guess.
Yeah, I like roles that keep things moving.
Totally. I’d be great at that.

text: You’re an illustrator — creating artwork for books, campaigns, and online content, working closely with clients and expressing your visual style.
scale: I’d be lost with a blank page.
Maybe if I had direction.
It could be fun creatively.
That sounds really fulfilling.
Yes. I’d love that kind of creative role.

text: Solving technical problems, debugging things, or improving how systems run sounds rewarding.
scale: Nope. That sounds tedious.
Only if it’s easy to fix.
I could give it a shot.
I like getting to the bottom of things.
Yes. I’d love to be the problem solver.

text: Managing a team, pitching investors, or leading big meetings sounds energizing, not scary.
scale: Terrifying. No thanks.
I’d need a lot of prep.
Maybe if I believed in the project.
I’d be excited by that kind of role.
Yes. I’d be in my element there.

text: You’re a personal trainer — guiding people through workouts, motivating them, and helping them hit their fitness goals.
scale: That sounds exhausting and awkward.
Only if I didn’t have to be too intense.
It could be rewarding to help people.
Yeah, I’d enjoy that kind of connection.
Yes. That role fits me really well.

text: I'd love a job where I get to work with animals, machinery, or my hands instead of a laptop.
scale: Please no. Keyboard life forever.
Only if it’s a short-term thing.
Maybe for part of the day.
That kind of mix actually sounds nice.
Yes. Let me be up and moving, not sitting.

text: A job where I get to invent things, pitch wild ideas, or challenge creative boundaries sounds amazing.
scale: Yikes. No thanks.
Only if there are rules in place.
Sounds fun, but also chaotic.
That’s the kind of challenge I like.
Yes. Wild ideas are where I live.

text: I often get ideas for businesses, products, or ways to improve things.
scale: Not really. I don’t think like that.
Maybe occasionally, but I forget them fast.
I get random ideas sometimes.
I think about improvement constantly.
Yes. I'm always spotting opportunity.

text: You're volunteering as a peer mentor for students trying to choose their career paths. You listen, ask questions, and share what you’ve learned.
scale: Nope. I wouldn’t know what to say.
Only if someone trained me first.
It depends on the student.
Yeah, I like helping others gain clarity.
Definitely. Guiding others feels deeply meaningful to me.

text: You're working on a farm-to-table project, tending to plants, handling tools, and being outside all day in shifting conditions.
scale: Absolutely not. That sounds like my nightmare.
Maybe, but only for a short time.
I could try it if the setting was nice.
Yeah, that kind of hands-on work feels grounding.
Totally. I'd love being immersed in nature and tools.

text: Organizing chaos into a clean, labeled system brings me a weird amount of joy.
scale: Mess is fine. I thrive in the void.
Structure is... meh. I’ll survive.
Okay, I admit — order has its perks.
It’s satisfying to bring logic to the madness.
Yes. I want folders in my folders. Bring it on.

text: I'd be happy in a job where I get to design, write, perform, or create visual content regularly.
scale: No thanks. That’s not my thing.
Only once in a while, maybe.
That could be fun in the right setting.
Yes, I’d get excited about that.
Absolutely. That’s where I feel most alive.

text: I often find myself asking questions like 'why does that work the way it does?'
scale: I don’t really care how things work.
I only ask that stuff by accident.
Sometimes I get curious, sure.
I catch myself nerding out on random things.
Yes. I constantly want to understand how things tick.

text: You’re working in a small clinic, helping people understand and manage their health. You explain things clearly and support them through tough emotions.
scale: No way. That’s way too personal.
Maybe, but only behind the scenes.
It could be rewarding in the right moment.
Yeah, I like being there for people.
Yes. I’d love helping people in that way.

text: It makes me happy when everything’s structured, categorized, and under control.
scale: Chaos is fine. I'm not here to sort anything.
It’s whatever. I'm not bothered either way.
I guess I like when things feel organized.
Clean systems bring me peace, honestly.
Yes. Structure is my love language.

text: You’re leading a team to write, produce, and perform a live theater show. It’s bold, collaborative, and creative chaos for weeks.
scale: No thank you. That’s way too much.
Maybe if I had a tiny role.
It sounds interesting but intense.
That sounds creatively fulfilling.
Yes. That’s totally my kind of environment.

text: Roles like sales, marketing, politics, or launching businesses sound exciting to me.
scale: Nope. I don't want to sell or persuade.
Maybe, but I’m skeptical.
I'd try it with the right product.
I think I'd actually enjoy that world.
Yes. That sounds like my zone.

text: You’re a mechanic — spending your day diagnosing car issues, working with tools, and fixing real problems with your hands.
scale: Hard pass. I'd destroy the engine and cry.
Maybe if someone walked me through it.
Could be satisfying in small doses.
Yeah, I like the idea of fixing things.
Yes. I’d thrive in that kind of hands-on role.

text: You’re part of a research team trying to figure out why a mysterious species of plant is dying out. It involves experiments, analysis, and digging through data for patterns.
scale: Ugh, sounds tedious and slow.
Might be fun with the right team.
I’d try it if I had a clear goal.
That sounds genuinely fascinating.
Yes. I’d love solving something like that.

text: You’re designing branding and visuals for a startup — color palettes, fonts, layout, the whole vibe. It’s creative freedom with a tight deadline.
scale: Sounds stressful and vague.
Only if I had strong direction.
That could be interesting if the brand’s cool.
Yeah, I’d enjoy shaping the aesthetic.
Absolutely. Give me creative control and a vision.

text: I could see myself pitching ideas to investors, leading a company, or growing a business someday.
scale: No thanks. I’d hate that pressure.
Only if I had to.
Maybe, if I believed in the idea.
Yeah, that would be a challenge I’d want.
Yes. That sounds like something I’d thrive in.

text: I’d love a job where talking with people, explaining things, and making them feel heard is the main focus.
scale: No thanks. I'm not a people person.
Only if I had to do it.
I could get into that role.
That actually sounds really meaningful.
Yes. I’m at my best in conversation.

text: Using tools and equipment to build or fix something physical sounds like a great day to me.
scale: Absolutely not. I'd rather watch paint dry.
Not really my vibe, but maybe once.
Could be okay in small doses.
Yeah, I'd probably enjoy that kind of work.
Totally. Let me fix, build, tinker — I'm in.

text: It matters to me that rules, roles, and expectations are clearly defined.
scale: Not at all. I prefer figuring it out as I go.
Only when things are super confusing.
It’s helpful, but not required.
Structure makes everything smoother.
Yes. Clear systems = clear minds.

text: I love solving problems that don’t have obvious answers — especially if it means digging deep into research or data.
scale: That sounds like a brain fog nightmare.
Only if someone else is guiding me.
Maybe — if I'm in the right headspace.
Honestly, that kind of thing gets me thinking.
Yes. Give me the puzzle. I'm fully invested.

text: I'd enjoy a role where I get to coach, mentor, or guide others.
scale: That sounds awkward and stressful.
Only if it’s a small part of the job.
Maybe, if I know what I’m doing.
That kind of guidance feels natural to me.
Absolutely. Helping others grow is my jam.

text: You’re outdoors building a custom treehouse from scratch. It involves carpentry, problem-solving, and working with your hands all day.
scale: Nope. That sounds exhausting.
Maybe, if the weather’s nice.
I’d be curious to try it once.
Honestly, that sounds satisfying.
Yes. That is my ideal kind of work.

text: You're organizing a community fundraiser. You’re in charge of the campaign strategy, messaging, outreach, and leading the volunteers.
scale: That sounds like way too much responsibility.
Maybe if someone else handled the logistics.
Could be rewarding in the right context.
I love leading efforts that make an impact.
Yes. That kind of leadership role excites me.

text: You're analyzing a massive dataset to figure out trends in education. You’re deep in spreadsheets, articles, and graphs all day.
scale: I’d fall asleep by hour one.
I could tolerate it for a good cause.
It depends on the topic — maybe.
I like finding meaning in numbers.
Yes. That kind of intellectual puzzle excites me.

text: I'd enjoy being a counselor, teacher, or coach — helping people directly with their growth.
scale: Nope. That’s way too personal.
Maybe in small doses.
I’d be open to trying something like that.
That sounds genuinely fulfilling.
Absolutely. Sign me up.
